Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 08:59AM ChocolateLover wrote: Yes, Robin, it is very difficult for us career gals to let that go. I had to picture my life as finite, and choose where to spend the rest of my time/energy. That may sound drastic, but even as we feel that we are forced into a choice that is not really made by us, but by this damn disease, it is in our best interests to support ourselves with rest, nutrition, love etc. Your DH will have your back - mine had been telling me to quit for yrs. Men really do want to be the "big chief" and take care of us. This may be the only way they can. We are very fortunate to have dh's in our lives. hugs to you.

Posts.Title: surviving high liver involvement? dantow pee

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 10:59AM ChocolateLover wrote: Patti, I had rads to my neck/throat 2 yrs ago and had lymph nodes removed prior to that. Yup - supraclaviular region. Other nodes just popped up instead.  My skin was raised and you could see bumps all over my neck and chest area.  I said no more surgery, everytime you take one out, two more pop up. Stupid surgeons just want to cut. Anyway, the rad.onc.said I "might" get a sore throat for a couple of days. HA! It felt like I drank a whole bottle of bleach and it took 3 weeks to heal.  I only had 10 days of rads, 10 minutes each time. They must have really blasted those nodes though.  Are your lumps lymph nodes? Mine were also in the soft tissue.  I had Caelyx chemo last year (a targeted form of Adriamycn) and it shrank them down though.  Now, I have no visible lumps, my skin is not prickly and hot and red anymore, and I have less plural effusion. I'd ask your onc. to try Caelyx. ? Good luck!!!
Posts.Title: rads to neck anyone? Tamoxinfen & Stage IV? pattih pattih

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 09:36PM ChocolateLover wrote: Gals, we are all inspirations to each other. I can't tell you how many times I log on and, not even posting, I smile, shed a tear, laugh out loud, nod my head in agreement, swear at the inept med. "professionals"; all with you. becoz of you. in support of you. All of you. you inspire me. Our strength is obvious, even thru the dark times. Our passion is life. Our love is strong and we are united; not only against this disease and what it can/has taken from us, but in our will to keep on living, loving, learning, laughing. We are hope itself. To all my bc sisters, thank you for the inspiration everyday. xo

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2010 05:03PM - edited Jun 25, 2010 05:04PM by ChocolateLover Sorry, I dont know about Gemzar/Cisplatin.  (edited to add this stmt) Can you ask your onc about Caelyx? I had AC when initially dx 10 yrs ago, and now they have improved the Adriamycin to be more targeted with less side effects. I had Caelyx 2 yrs ago and kept my hair, didnt feel very nauseus and was only moderately tired. It's still red, btw. and it might give you better results. good luck! I also had horrible se's on Paclitaxel (heart effusions). ps: I've been on the Xeloda now for 6 months and it might be starting to fail. Test results on Tuesday. since I've already done Caelyx, I have no idea what's next. maybe Navelbine ?  hugs & hope for you.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 08:50PM ChocolateLover wrote: oh Daisy, I'm sorry about this news! Another biopsy totally sucks! Regarding feeling sorry for yourself with stage II, and having perspective now; perspective changes from day to day. Us stage IV gals have good days and bad, painful days and pain free days, dark gloomy days, and bright happy days. You know, it's basically easier to just take one day, one hour, sometimes one moment at a time. Do not deny your emotions. I'm glad to see you were relieved after your "breakdown". I have had many myself. It helps. Keep posting, we are here for you. And remember, many of us with stage IV are still enjoying life 5,6,7,8,9 even 10 years later! (me) Hugs & Hope, Choc.

I feel like I will never stop taking chemo and that's probably my reality. I know eventually my body will not be able to handle all the se's, as well as manage to keep fighting the cancer. But I will not give up on myself. My body may fail, but my spirit will keep soaring.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 12:02PM ChocolateLover wrote: Dear Daisy, I am do happy to see your latest post. you just sound calmer, not as frantic. It is so much better when we can think clearly, right?! I must tell you that when I was dx as stage IV, at 31, I too wanted to have children still. Most days even now, I wish I had kids. I was never given the opportunity to gather eggs or have them frozen, or whatever the procedure is. The dr's just wanted to rush and get going on new tx. And becoz the cancer is ER+, that means hormone tx for sure. They put me into medical menopause, and it would be impossible now to get any eggs becoz I'd have to come off the drugs to do so. (and chance advancing the cancer, no way!) Basically, I'm saying, that 10 yrs down the road I sure wish I had done that. So really search your heart and think about what a full happy life means to you. Adoption can be very difficult, maybe impossible, when you are dx as stage IV. There are other threads here that address that. And know that the possibility of living another 5, 10, 15, 20 yrs is very real. Long enough to raise happy, healthy kids? Besides, another 10 yrs will bring many more tx for BC for sure! My doc's said, we're not worried about a future life, we're concentrating on saving yours. Well...that scared the crap out of me. But now, in hindsight, my advice would be to make them give you ALL of your options. good luck with everything, hugs & hope
